image.altText: Vladimir Putin speaking in black suit and tie flanked by Russian flag.

items.synopsis: Russia's President Vladimir Putin has used a late night address to promise Wagner troops can go to Belarus, join Russia, or be with their families.

title.children: Putin addresses Russia after Wagner uprising

image.altText: Wagner mercenary fighters on top of a tank, with a Wagner flag.

items.synopsis: A former Russian diplomat who defected from his post at the United Nations in 2022 says Vladimir Putin's inner circle is shrinking and most people inside the Kremlin do not support the war against Ukraine.

title.children: 'Majority of people in the Kremlin unhappy about this war', Russia defector reveals

image.altText: The PwC logo is shown on an office building.

items.synopsis: In a sublime combination of breathtaking arrogance and dazzling ineptitude, the Australian arm of global accounting giant PwC has managed to turn a possible crime into a national crisis and then allowed it to evolve into a catastrophe, writes Ian Verrender.

title.children: PwC hacks off an arm, but still won't come clean

image.altText: A submersible under sea with air bubbles coming out from the top.

items.synopsis: An international investigation into the cause of the undersea implosion of a tourist submersible that killed all five people on board is underway. So, what happens next?

title.children: What happens next with the wreckage of OceanGate's submersible Titan?

image.altText: Nvidia logo displayed on a mobile phone screen with a circuit board in the background.

items.synopsis: The company behind much of the technology fuelling artificial intelligence has seen its shares surge almost 200 per cent this year as part of a wider AI boom, but are those sky-high valuations justified?

title.children: Nvidia's stock has surged almost 200 per cent on the back of AI. But will it stay there?

image.altText: Ashleigh Gardner with her hands raised on a cricket field with two other players visible.

items.synopsis: Ashleigh Gardner produces the second-best bowling match figures by a woman in history to spin her side to an 89-run Ashes Test victory over England at Trent Bridge.

title.children: Ash Gardner produces history to lead Australian women to Ashes Test triumph

image.altText: The back of a Victoria Police officer on duty.

items.synopsis: Victoria Police has been accused of racial profiling, with newly released data revealing people of African or Middle Eastern appearance received a disproportionate number of COVID-19 fines in the first year of the pandemic.

title.children: People of African, Middle Eastern appearance over-represented in Victorian COVID fines, data shows

image.altText: A woman wearing a hair net and apron stands on a factory production line with co-workers assembling speakers

items.synopsis: Australia is relying on its largest trading partner to bounce back, but China's youth unemployment figures and low consumer confidence are slowing down much-needed growth, suggesting a full recovery will take some time.

title.children: Australia's biggest trading partner is dealing with slow growth, reduced consumption and unemployed graduates

image.altText: Black and white photo of Nel Law smiling slightly with closed mouth, against plain background, wearing woolen turtleneck jumper.

items.synopsis: The rules prevented women from going to Antarctica in the 1960s, but Nel Law defied them. Now author Rachael Mead wants more people to learn about Nel's legacy.

title.children: 'A tragedy that she isn't more well known': The 1960s trailblazer who paved the way for women in Antarctica

image.altText: Gwenda Darling, a woman with pink hair, stands in a garden wearing a black scarf and striped jumper.

items.synopsis: Gwenda struggled with her dementia diagnosis at first, but now she's looking forward to the future and "living her best life".

title.children: 'My family lost the person they loved': How Gwenda came back from despair after her dementia diagnosis

image.altText: A close up photo of what appears to be orange citrus fruit with blue-grey mould on it

items.synopsis: Usually, mould spores are invisible — but give them a niche to exploit and you'll get all kinds of colours on the things in your home, writes Michael Taylor.

title.children: Black, blue, yellow or pink: What do the different colours of mould in my house mean?

image.altText: Jennifer Howard holding a small dog

items.synopsis: An Adelaide not-for-profit organisation that helps struggling pet owners says the housing crisis has pushed demand for its services to record levels, forcing it to turn some people away.

title.children: Animal shelters inundated as SA pet owners seeking rentals make 'heartbreaking' choices

image.altText: One basketballer shoots and another attempts to spoil.

items.synopsis: Seventeen years after she was part of a golden moment with the Opals, basketballer and four-time Olympian Laura Hodges has stepped back onto the court.

title.children: This former Opal couldn't resist the temptation of another shot at glory

image.altText: The outside of a building with a winding footpath surrounding garden beds.

items.synopsis: Canberra's only inpatient end-of-life hospice, Clare Holland House, will transition to ACT government control along with the Calvary Public Hospital in Bruce next month.

title.children: ACT government to take over Calvary-run hospice Clare Holland House

image.altText: A security fence lines an empty block of land.

items.synopsis: The High Court dismisses a bid by Russia to prevent the Commonwealth from taking control of a site it leased for a new embassy.

title.children: High Court throws out Russia's bid to stop Australian government taking control of embassy site

image.altText: An aerial shot of the construction of a new airport in Sydney.

items.synopsis: The long-awaited preliminary flight paths for Western Sydney Airport are now public, but the online tool where residents can search an address will be made available later this morning.

title.children: Flight paths revealed for new multi-billion-dollar Sydney airport

image.altText: Two workers in safety gear install solar panels on the roof of a home.

items.synopsis: Under changes to the ACT government's Sustainable Household Scheme, only properties with an unimproved land value of $450,000 or less can apply for an interest-free loan to install solar products.

title.children: Interest-free loans for solar will soon be restricted for Canberra households while encouraged for apartments

image.altText: A person lights a candle outside a nightclub, they are surrounded by floral tributes.

items.synopsis: The Colorado nightclub shooter is sentenced to life in prison after pleading guilty to the "intentional" death of five victims.

title.children: Colorado LGBTQ+ nightclub shooter sentenced to life in prison

image.altText: Wreck of a small black car strapped on to the back of a tow truck.

items.synopsis: Wendy Elizabeth Chattaway, 51, is charged with predatory driving in relation to the horror crash which saw a car hit a pole and roll into a water channel in regional NSW.

title.children: Woman chased car, causing it to crash and kill four, police say

image.altText: Waterfalls around Uluru

items.synopsis: The region is expected to see "excess" rainfall and extremely cold temperatures this week. There's even a chance of snow on the highest peaks.

title.children: Big chill and plenty of rain heading for Central Australia

image.altText: The outline of a woman, obscured, in front of a sign for Mindil Beach

items.synopsis: In her opening address, counsel assisting the coroner wonders whether the woman "would have been okay that night" had her partner been arrested when police had spoken to him twice earlier that day.

title.children: DV inquest hears attacker 'should have been arrested' hours before fatal assault

image.altText: A father and daughter stand out the front of netball courts, the daughter is holding a netball.

items.synopsis: The cost of sport has long been an issue for Canberra families and with the rising cost of living there are now calls for a sports voucher scheme to keep kids in the game.

title.children: Nine-year-old Amelia had to give up netball because of the cost. A sports voucher scheme might have helped her stay in the game

image.altText: A wooden sign marks the entrance of the new Bundaberg Brewed Drinks premises

items.synopsis: The men were taken to Bundaberg Hospital, where three are in a stable condition and one is in a serious condition.

title.children: Four men suffer facial burns in gas explosion at Bundaberg brewing company

image.altText: A man walking out of court with a woman.

items.synopsis: Lawyers for four men, who admitted stealing "gold dust" from a Kalgoorlie mine site, have described their clients' bungled heist as an "unsophisticated attempt" and a "stupid idea".

title.children: Four men fined over 'unsophisticated, stupid' gold dust theft from Kalgoorlie mine

image.altText: Duchess Sarah Ferguson standing in front of a dark background looking off-camera.

items.synopsis: The 63-year-old has undergone a successful single mastectomy after being diagnosed with early-stage breast cancer during a routine mammogram.

title.children: 'Don't wait': Sarah Ferguson, Duchess of York, urges people to get screened for cancer

image.altText: A sad man walks off a footy field.

items.synopsis: As the Eagles' nuclear winter drags on, the club says it is committed to staying the course — but can stalwarts like chief executive Trevor Nisbett and coach Adam Simpson survive?

title.children: Bad luck or bad management? As the West Coast Eagles flounder, pressure mounts on coach and CEO

image.altText: Picture of a large crowd on a road in front of an old building

items.synopsis: An army spokesperson says three senior officers have been sacked for failing to avert violent clashes.

title.children: Pakistan army officers sacked over violence by Imran Khan's supporters

image.altText: A man with his face blurred is flanked by several police officers as he's led to a police van

items.synopsis: Six men are charged with affray after an alleged fight broke out between members and associates of the underworld crew in the city last week.

title.children: 'Immense pressure': Police land blow to Alameddine crew after Sydney CBD brawl

image.altText: Two men in suits walk down a footpath, one in front of the other. The one in front is shielding his face with a clipboard.

items.synopsis: Troy Robert Cridland denies he knowingly had sexual intercourse with a girl under 16 as the end of the trial in northern NSW approaches.

title.children: Jury to decide issues of 'critical importance' in trial of former police officer accused of sex with underage girl

image.altText: A fire breaks out on a road at night time, shot from inside a fire truck.

items.synopsis: A warning is in place for parts of southern NSW as emergency services and power providers are working to repair damage caused by gale-force wind.

title.children: Wild 100kph winds cause fires, blackouts, property damage on NSW south coast

image.altText: A close up of Barilaro with his eyebrows raised during questioning.

items.synopsis: John Barilaro's solicitor argues a camera operator is "having his cake and eating it too" by being awarded both the cost of repairs and a replacement camera.

title.children: John Barilaro found liable for damaging camera operator's equipment during scuffle

image.altText: Cattle stand before several wind turbines.

items.synopsis: A study by sleep researchers at Flinders University finds that noise generated by wind farms is no more disruptive to sleep than traffic noise.

title.children: Wind farm noise no worse than traffic, study by sleep researchers finds

image.altText: aerial of remote hospital near water

items.synopsis: Three people are dying from avoidable causes in Torres Strait communities each week, leaders say, and they're calling for an independent review into the regional health service.

title.children: Leaders plead for 'avoidable' weekly deaths to be stopped in Torres Strait hospitals

image.altText: A man stands in front of rural land with two dams.

items.synopsis: Adelaide Hills property owners downstream of a dam at risk of failing following torrential rain fear a potential cascade effect, with another dam directly in the firing line if the top one gives way.

title.children: Risk of dam breach domino effect has residents praying 'that everything holds'

image.altText: A woman looks into the camera with a small child in her left arm, and holding a slightly older child's hand with her right.

items.synopsis: A study has found caregivers of young children — more often than not women — were faced with challenging situations as they tried to care for their children and keep safe.

title.children: Parents pushed to the brink and 'running on adrenaline', Black Summer survey finds
